overview: Develop spatial reasoning through proof, construction, and measurement. Master plane and solid figures.
naturalProgression: Start with geometric vocabulary and angle relationships - the language of geometry
Move to triangles and prove congruence using postulates and theorems
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem and introduce trigonometry
Extend to polygons, quadrilateral properties, and circle theorems
Explore similarity, 3D geometry, and coordinate proofs

aiInstructionModel.description: The AI tutor leads all instruction using the gradual release model (I Do / We Do / You Do) but has full freedom to make instructional decisions. Module files provide scope, key concepts, teaching guidance, and reference problems—NOT rigid scripts. The AI decides pacing, chooses examples, adjusts scaffolding, and personalizes based on the student's skill mastery, learning profile, and real-time responses.

phases.aiRole: Build conceptual understanding before procedures. The AI introduces the BIG IDEA using real-world connections, student interests, and visual/physical analogies. The AI chooses HOW to introduce based on the student's learning style.
phases.studentRole: Engage with the concept, ask questions, make predictions

phases.aiRole: Model 2-3 worked examples with think-aloud reasoning. The AI selects problem difficulty based on the student's current mastery and explains using the student's preferred style (visual, verbal, step-by-step, etc.).
phases.studentRole: Observe, ask clarifying questions, identify patterns

phases.aiRole: Quick comprehension check before moving to practice. The AI asks 1-2 targeted questions to verify the student grasps the concept, not just the procedure. If gaps detected, the AI re-teaches before proceeding.
phases.studentRole: Explain understanding in own words, answer concept questions

phases.aiRole: Guided practice with adaptive scaffolding. The AI provides problems and supports the student through them, offering hints ONLY when needed. Scaffolding decreases as the student demonstrates understanding. The AI decides when to move on.
phases.studentRole: Attempt problems with AI support, explain reasoning

phases.aiRole: Emotional and confidence assessment. The AI checks how the student FEELS about the material—not just accuracy. Adjusts pacing and tone based on anxiety, confidence, and engagement signals.
phases.studentRole: Reflect on confidence and comfort level

phases.aiRole: Independent practice. The AI presents problems and steps back, allowing the student to work independently. Minimal hints—only if the student is stuck. The AI evaluates accuracy, independence, and transfer.

Formal assessment for skill mastery. The AI determines if the student has met the 4-Pillar mastery criteria (accuracy, independence, transfer, retention). Awards mastery or identifies areas for re-teaching.

aiDecisionRights: Choose which examples and problems to present (module provides reference problems, AI may generate its own)
Adjust difficulty in real-time based on student performance
Skip or extend phases based on student readiness
Re-order skills within a module if pedagogically appropriate
Generate additional practice or enrichment as needed
Use student interests and learning profile to personalize examples
Decide when to advance to the next skill or re-teach
Select teaching strategies (visual, algebraic, physical, verbal) based on student profile
Adjust tone and pacing based on emotional signals and anxiety level

modules.title: Geometric Foundations & Angles
modules.preview: Build vocabulary and understand angle relationships.
essentialQuestions: How do undefined terms form the foundation of geometric reasoning?
How do angle relationships help us solve real-world problems?
What patterns emerge when parallel lines are cut by a transversal?

lessons.title: Points, Lines, and Planes
concepts: Line segments, rays, and proper notation
lessons.teachingNotes: Use physical models—laser pointer (line), GPS pin (point), tabletop (plane). Emphasize proper notation from day one.

lessons.title: Measuring and Classifying Angles
concepts: Acute, right, obtuse, straight angle classification
lessons.teachingNotes: Have students estimate angle measures before using a protractor to build number sense for angles.

lessons.title: Angle Pair Relationships
commonMistakes: Forgetting that vertical angles are always congruent

lessons.title: Parallel Lines and Transversals
keyFormulas: If lines are parallel: corresponding angles are congruent, alternate interior are congruent, same-side interior are supplementary
lessons.teachingNotes: Use F, Z, and C letter patterns as visual mnemonics.

lessons.title: Solving with Transversal Angle Relationships
concepts: Setting up equations from angle relationships
Using congruent angles: set expressions equal
Using supplementary angles: set expressions summing to 180
Finding all 8 angles from one given angle
commonMistakes: Setting supplementary angles equal instead of summing to 180

modules.title: Triangle Foundations
modules.preview: Classify triangles and apply angle sum theorem.
essentialQuestions: How do we use classification to understand the properties of triangles?
Why do the angles of a triangle always sum to 180?
What constraints determine whether three lengths can form a triangle?

lessons.title: Classifying Triangles
concepts: By angles: acute, right, obtuse, equiangular
lessons.teachingNotes: Use Venn diagrams to show relationships between triangle types.

lessons.title: Triangle Angle Sum Theorem
keyFormulas: angle A + angle B + angle C = 180
lessons.teachingNotes: Physical demonstration: tear triangle corners and arrange on a straight line.

lessons.title: Exterior Angle Theorem
concepts: Exterior angle = sum of two remote interior angles
Setting up equations with exterior angles
Exterior angle is always greater than either remote interior angle

lessons.title: Triangle Inequality Theorem
concepts: Sum of any two sides must be greater than the third side
Shortcut: add two shortest sides, compare to longest
Finding range of possible third side lengths
commonMistakes: Using greater-than-or-equal instead of strictly greater-than

modules.title: Triangle Congruence
modules.preview: Prove triangles congruent using SSS, SAS, ASA, AAS, HL.
essentialQuestions: What minimum information do we need to guarantee two triangles are congruent?
How does proving congruence unlock information about corresponding parts (CPCTC)?
How do we construct a logical argument (proof) in geometry?

lessons.title: What is Congruence?
concepts: Why checking all 6 parts is unnecessary

lessons.title: SSS and SAS Postulates
concepts: SSS: three pairs of congruent sides
SAS: two sides and the INCLUDED angle
Why SSA does NOT work (ambiguous case)
lessons.teachingNotes: Use color-coded corresponding parts on diagrams. Demonstrate SSA failure with flexible model.

lessons.title: ASA, AAS, and HL Theorems
concepts: ASA: two angles and the included side
AAS: two angles and a non-included side
HL: hypotenuse-leg for right triangles only
lessons.teachingNotes: HL only works for RIGHT triangles—always check for the right angle first.

lessons.title: CPCTC
concepts: Corresponding Parts of Congruent Triangles are Congruent
CPCTC used AFTER proving congruence, never before
Using CPCTC to find missing side/angle measures
The proof flow: Given -> Prove congruent -> CPCTC

lessons.title: Writing Congruence Proofs
concepts: Common reasons: Given, Definition of midpoint, Vertical angles, Reflexive property
Planning a proof strategy before writing
lessons.teachingNotes: Teach proof writing as 'telling a story with reasons'. Each statement needs justification.

modules.title: Right Triangles
modules.preview: Master Pythagorean theorem and special right triangles.
essentialQuestions: Why is the Pythagorean Theorem one of the most useful theorems in mathematics?
How do special right triangle ratios eliminate the need for calculation?
How do trigonometric ratios connect angles to side lengths?

lessons.title: The Pythagorean Theorem
concepts: a^2 + b^2 = c^2 for right triangles only
c is always the hypotenuse (longest side, opposite right angle)
Solving for a missing leg vs. solving for hypotenuse
lessons.teachingNotes: Use the visual proof with squares on each side to make it concrete.

lessons.title: Converse of the Pythagorean Theorem
concepts: If a^2 + b^2 = c^2, the triangle is right
If a^2 + b^2 > c^2, the triangle is acute
If a^2 + b^2 < c^2, the triangle is obtuse
Always compare to the LONGEST side squared

lessons.title: Special Right Triangles
concepts: Finding missing sides using ratios, not Pythagorean Theorem
Recognizing when to use special triangle shortcuts
lessons.teachingNotes: Teach the ratio patterns rather than memorizing specific numbers.

lessons.title: Introduction to Trigonometric Ratios
concepts: Using trig to find missing sides
lessons.teachingNotes: Opposite and adjacent change depending on the reference angle.

lessons.title: Trig Applications: Angles of Elevation and Depression
concepts: Setting up and solving real-world trig problems
commonMistakes: Confusing angle of elevation with angle of depression

modules.title: Q2 Checkpoint
modules.preview: Cumulative assessment: Congruence and right triangles

modules.title: Polygons & Quadrilaterals
modules.preview: Explore angle sums and properties of special quadrilaterals.
essentialQuestions: How does the triangle angle sum extend to all polygons?
How is the quadrilateral family organized by properties?
How do we prove properties of quadrilaterals using both synthetic and coordinate methods?

lessons.title: Polygon Interior Angle Sum
concepts: Formula: (n-2) * 180 where n = number of sides
Deriving formula by triangulating from one vertex
Each angle of a regular polygon: (n-2)*180/n
Working backwards: finding n from angle sum

lessons.title: Polygon Exterior Angle Sum
concepts: Exterior angles of any convex polygon sum to 360
Each exterior angle of a regular polygon = 360/n
Finding number of sides from exterior angle
keyFormulas: Each exterior angle of regular polygon = 360/n

lessons.title: Properties of Parallelograms
lessons.teachingNotes: Build the quadrilateral hierarchy as a family tree.

lessons.title: Rectangles, Rhombi, and Squares
concepts: Rectangle: parallelogram with 4 right angles, congruent diagonals
Rhombus: parallelogram with 4 congruent sides, perpendicular diagonals
Square: both rectangle AND rhombus (inherits all properties)
lessons.teachingNotes: Every property of a parent is inherited by children in the hierarchy.

lessons.title: Trapezoids and Kites
concepts: Trapezoid: exactly one pair of parallel sides (bases)
Isosceles trapezoid: congruent legs, congruent base angles, congruent diagonals
Midsegment = average of the two bases
Kite: two pairs of consecutive congruent sides, perpendicular diagonals

modules.title: Circles
modules.preview: Study circle theorems, arcs, sectors, and inscribed angles.
essentialQuestions: How does the central angle act as a 'fraction controller' for arc length and sector area?
What is the relationship between inscribed angles and central angles?
How do tangent and secant relationships extend circle theorems?

lessons.title: Circle Vocabulary, Circumference, and Area
concepts: Radius, diameter, chord, secant, tangent definitions

lessons.title: Arc Length and Sector Area
concepts: The central angle controls the fraction
Working backwards to find the central angle
lessons.teachingNotes: Pizza analogy: the central angle determines what fraction of the pizza you're taking.

lessons.title: Inscribed Angle Theorem
concepts: Inscribed angle = half the central angle (same arc)
Inscribed angles intercepting same arc are congruent
Opposite angles of inscribed quadrilateral are supplementary
lessons.teachingNotes: The inscribed angle theorem is the 'master theorem' that unlocks most circle angle problems.

lessons.title: Tangent and Chord Angle Relationships
concepts: Tangent is perpendicular to radius at point of tangency
Two tangent segments from external point are congruent

lessons.title: Chord and Segment Relationships
concepts: Intersecting chords: product of segments are equal
Setting up and solving segment equations

modules.title: Similarity
modules.preview: Apply similarity theorems and solve proportions.
essentialQuestions: How is similarity different from congruence, and how are they related?
How do proportional reasoning and similarity solve real-world measurement problems?
What role does the geometric mean play in right triangles?

lessons.title: Similar Figures and Scale Factors
concepts: Corresponding angles congruent, corresponding sides proportional
Scale factor as ratio of corresponding sides
Solving proportions to find missing sides
lessons.teachingNotes: Distinguish from congruence: congruence is similarity with scale factor 1.

lessons.title: Triangle Similarity Theorems
concepts: AA: two pairs of congruent angles
SSS~: all three pairs of sides proportional
SAS~: two proportional sides and included congruent angle
Writing similarity statements with correct correspondence
lessons.teachingNotes: AA is most commonly used—if two angles match, the third is forced.

lessons.title: Geometric Mean and Right Triangle Altitude
concepts: Geometric mean of a and b = sqrt(a*b)
Altitude on hypotenuse creates two similar triangles
Leg rule: leg^2 = adjacent segment * hypotenuse

modules.title: Three-Dimensional Geometry
modules.preview: Calculate surface area and volume of prisms, cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres.
essentialQuestions: Why is the volume of a pyramid exactly one-third the volume of the corresponding prism?
How do 2D shapes connect to 3D surface area and volume calculations?
How do we choose the right formula for a given real-world 3D problem?

lessons.title: Volume of Prisms and Cylinders
lessons.teachingNotes: Always identify the BASE SHAPE first—that determines which area formula to use for B.

lessons.title: Volume of Pyramids, Cones, and Spheres
concepts: Pyramid/Cone: V = (1/3)Bh — exactly 1/3 of corresponding prism/cylinder

lessons.title: Surface Area of Prisms and Cylinders
lessons.teachingNotes: Surface area = wrapping paper. Unfold the shape (net) to see all flat surfaces.

lessons.title: Surface Area of Pyramids, Cones, and Spheres
concepts: Pyramid: SA = B + (1/2)Pl (slant height, not vertical height!)
Finding slant height with Pythagorean Theorem
commonMistakes: Using vertical height instead of slant height for lateral area

modules.title: Coordinate Geometry
modules.preview: Apply algebra to geometric concepts on the coordinate plane.
essentialQuestions: How does the distance formula connect to the Pythagorean Theorem?
How can we use algebra to prove geometric properties on the coordinate plane?
What does the equation of a circle tell us about its graph?

lessons.title: Distance and Midpoint Formulas
concepts: Distance formula derived from Pythagorean Theorem
lessons.teachingNotes: Draw the right triangle formed by two points to show the Pythagorean connection.

lessons.title: Parallel and Perpendicular Slopes
concepts: Perpendicular lines: negative reciprocal slopes (m1 * m2 = -1)
Writing equations of parallel/perpendicular lines through a point

lessons.title: Equation of a Circle
concepts: Signs in equation are opposite the center coordinates
Finding equation from endpoints of a diameter
commonMistakes: Forgetting the right side is r-squared not r

lessons.title: Coordinate Proofs
concepts: Using distance to prove sides congruent
Using slope to prove lines parallel or perpendicular
Proving triangle/quadrilateral classifications on the coordinate plane
lessons.teachingNotes: Coordinate proofs combine algebra and geometry—use distance, slope, and midpoint as proof tools.

modules.title: Final Mastery Assessment
modules.preview: Comprehensive assessment covering all Geometry content

aiGuidanceNotes: Geometry builds spatial reasoning and logical proof skills. Start with vocabulary and angle relationships as the language of geometry. Congruence and similarity require understanding correspondence—use color coding. The Pythagorean Theorem is the bridge between geometry and algebra. Proof writing should feel like 'telling a story with reasons', not filling in a template. Connect every topic to real-world applications: architecture, engineering, navigation, art.
